page.title: 13LAW AND ORDER
page.content: The village of Camber is polliced by a constable who knows most of the residents. During the summer months the population swells from about 1000 to upwards of 20,000 people, and on a hot summer's day, especially if it is a weekend. Two constables who live in the village, whose duties are usually in Rye, patrol the village in the summer months. Most of the offences that have to be dealt with are minor thefts and damage to cars. The police also cope with scores of lost and found children, and keep an eye on beach barbeques when enthusiastic youngsters, full of joie-de-vivre, with radios at full blast, and people sleeping nearby. The police endeavour to keep a balance, letting the young have fun without disturbing the local populace.
